text:
HODGES: The basic goal of
12.000 is to provide freshman at

MIT with an opportunity to put
together concepts and ideas that

they get in a more formal way,
in particular in the science

core at MIT in their first year
and put those in turn together

with social issues,
fundamental social issues in

the context of big environmental
problems.

The subject changes from year
to year in terms of its theme.

We tend to focus on different
areas at different times.

But, on the other hand,
the overarching goal is to have

them think about how you
approach really complicated

problems that require multiple
perspectives and don't necessary

have any simple solutions.
I mean most of the problems

that they tend to deal with,
in the other subjects that they

take in the freshman year,
have straightforward known

solutions.
So it's like taking a problem

set, working on it and solving
those problems in particular.

But most of the problems that
really keep you awake at night

are not those kinds of problems.
And so, as a consequence,

this puts us in a position that
we can literally let them think

a little bit about what it is
like to solve cutting-edge

problems that have no simple
answers.

The course is structured in
such a way that students get

grades based on their individual
work.

They get grades based on
teamwork.

And they get grades as an
entire class.

And those are different
components of the overall grade

for the class.
The reason for that kind of

structure is that,
in particular,

we are trying to emphasize team
learning and teamwork in this

subject.
And so, by setting up the grade

structure in such a way that a
substantial proportion of the

grade, far more than half the
grade actually depends on the

overall outcome for the class
and the overall outcome for the

individual teams that make up
the class.

It began, a number of years
ago, as an experiment that was

supported by the d'arbeloff Fund
here at MIT, really an

experiment in project-based,
team-based learning

specifically directed at
freshman.

And it was specifically
supposed to be interdisciplinary

right from the get-go.
So what has happened is it has

been used as a model over the
years to try and think about how

one would run that kind of a
subject for freshman in

particular.
Because one of the big problems

that we all have with freshman
education at MIT is the balance

between the incredible
intellectual capacity of the

freshman who come in versus the
amount of training that they

have and, therefore,
their sophistication in looking

at problems.
So lots of people would argue

that project-based learning is
best done, for example,

in the junior year or the
senior year or even in the

graduate years.
But one of the things that we

found out from this class is
that, even though students don't

necessarily have a lot of the
formal training that forms the

foundation for high-level
learning they have a tremendous

amount of creativity.
And this really builds a

self-confidence in them to work
on problems that normally they

would perceive as problems that
are insolvable for them.

12.000 is not a formal subject
within the departmental

curriculum of EAPS,
although it can count as a

restrictive elective for
students who are taking the

environmental science track
within our departmental program.

However, it is really meant as
an opportunity for freshman to

think very broadly about their
own education and how they learn

things, how they put together
solutions to these big

complicated problems.
I think one of the highlights

of this class is the final
presentation at the end of the

academic year,
sorry, at the end of the

semester.
And the rationale behind that

is that I wanted to give the
students a sense that if they do

work well and if they come up
with an effective solution to

one of these complicated
problems that they will be paid

attention to.
I mean this is part of building

this sense of empowerment among
these students.

So the simplest way,
the best way to do that is to

put them in a position where
they are trying to explain their

solution to a bunch of people
who are themselves deeply

immersed in that particular
problem.

And they really have a
knowledge of the issues that

surround any solution that
particular problem.

So every year,
for the final presentation,

I invite a panel of maybe five
or six people who have special

knowledge of this particular
area or have special knowledge

of the kinds of problems that
are confronted by that

particular class.
And one of the things that I

have found is that has been a
tremendous motivator,

a far greater motivator than
the grades that students would

get in this class,
because there is no fear like

the fear of looking stupid in
front of a bunch of people who

know what they are talking
about.

We also do a live webcast of
that final presentation for a

variety of reasons.
We started doing it because we

wanted to have it for assessment
purposes, not for what a

particular class does but for
assessment for the subject as a

whole.
By looking back at those from

year to year we can sort of see
what seemed to have worked well

pedagogically,
what didn't seem to have worked

well pedagogically,
and we can get a sense of how

well the students are really
learning the material that way,

I think more so than we could
by, for example,

entrance and exit examples.
With this kind of material it

is hard to devise those anyway,
but we can do it well because I

always believe that the better
you can articulate a problem the

more you understand it.
I think one of the most

difficult things about teaching
this subject is that you have to

stop being a professor and you
have to let the students do the

work on their own.
Throughout the years you find

that the students are going to
stumble and they are going to

make mistakes and they do things
really inefficiently in a

subject of this kind.
If you create an environment

for learning but you don't
actually hold the control stick

for the learning of the students
then it is a little bit of a

scary thing.
You believe every year,

I believe that the system is
beginning to be chaotic and it

is not going to work very
effectively.

And then at the end of every
year, every semester that I

teach this class the students
come out of it beautifully.

And I think that is a
testimonial, not to anything

that I do, but a testimonial to
their capacity to learn as a
group but also as individuals.
